$BTC  is at a proper battleground right now, and long‚Äëterm holders are finally taking some chips off the table.  Over the past days, spending from older wallets has picked up noticeably, which usually means early cohorts are selling into strength after the run to new highs. That supply is now meeting a more cautious market, with macro risk‚Äëoff and ETF flows no longer in ‚Äúfull send‚Äù mode.  Why 85K matters: ‚Ä¢ It‚Äôs a big psychological level and a clear pivot on the chart. ‚Ä¢ A lot of recent spot and ETF buyers are anchored around the mid‚Äë80Ks. ‚Ä¢ Order books and open interest have been clustering in this zone.  From here, it‚Äôs basically two paths: ‚Ä¢ Scenario 1: 85K holds (or is quickly reclaimed). That would signal that institutions and dip‚Äëbuyers are absorbing long‚Äëterm holder supply, and BTC can chop in an 85‚Äì95K range while the market digests profit‚Äëtaking. ‚Ä¢ Scenario 2: Slow bleed toward 80K. If price accepts below 85K and bounces keep getting sold, the market will naturally probe the next liquidity pocket around 80K (and possibly the high‚Äë70Ks) before stronger demand steps in.  Right now, the tape looks more like an ownership rotation than a full trend break: old coins moving to new hands, with 85K as the current line in the sand. Whether we bounce here or finish the move closer to 80K depends less on long‚Äëterm holders, and more on how aggressively fresh capital is willing to buy this dip.

#Metaplanet  Plans $137M Raise to Expand $BTC  Holdings  Metaplanet completed a board-approved financing structure Thursday that will raise $79.5 million immediately through new share issuance, with the potential to generate up to $137 million total if attached warrants are exercised over the next year.  The Tokyo-listed company will issue 24.53 million common shares at 499 yen per share, representing a 5% premium to the prior closing price. Each share includes 0.65 #stockacquisition  rights, totaling 15.94 million potential additional shares exercisable at 547 yen through Feb. 15, 2027.  CEO Simon Gerovich announced the completion roughly an hour after a formal notice detailed approval from the board of directors on Jan. 29. The securities are being placed directly with select overseas investors through a third-party allotment rather than sold publicly on open markets.  Approximately $91.2 million from the net proceeds will fund additional $BTC  purchases between February 2026 and February 2027. The company stated in its notice that acquiring more #Bitcoin  will strengthen its financial foundation and enhance its value preservation function under macroeconomic conditions characterized by fiat currency depreciation and inflationary pressures.  Another $10.1 million supports the Bitcoin Income business segment, which generates revenue through derivative and options transactions on $BTC . The company expects this division to contribute $57.8 million in revenue for fiscal 2025, up from a previous projection of $44 million.

Crypto savings accounts enable investors to gain interest on digital assets without expansion. The highest volume exchanges, such as Bitget, Nexo, Coinbase, Binance, and Crypto(.)com, have flexible savings, fixed deposits, staking, structured earns, and withdrawal plans in 2026.  What is a crypto savings account and what is its functionality?  The deposits are placed in the crypto interest on products deposit Flexible products enable users to withdraw money within minutes, Yields are determined by asset, demand and structure, and stablecoins have more predictable returns.  In 2026, which are the platforms that have the best crypto savings account?  Best platforms compromise yield, coverage, and convenience:  Bitget: Staking, fixed, flexible, structured, and DeFi products in 100+ assets with good yield.  Flexible and fixed savings with greater returns through levels of loyalty.  Coinbase: Stake conservative and USDC incentives on regulatory clarity.  Binance: Expansive earn items that have variable returns and coverage.  Crypto(.)com: Better rates with greater lock-ups and flexible products that are higher in rate.  What are the savings products that Bitget has?  Bitget offers flexible savings, fixed term, staking, structured products, automatic interest accrual and daily predictable payouts.  Conclusion  One of the most popular strategies of passive income in 2026 is crypto savings. Although Nexo, Coinbase, Binance, and Cryptocurrency(.)com are available in various styles, Bitget is a top provider of high yields, wide asset coverage, and custom-made products.  FAQs  Is it safe to have crypto savings accounts? Best exchanges eliminate risk by means of custody systems and reserve disclosure, yet market and platform risk persists. From a technical analysis standpoint,       $BTC is currently at a key decision zone.

85K is a major psychological and structural support. On the daily chart, this level aligns with previous consolidation and high-volume node on the VPVR. As long as    $BTC holds above 85K, the market structure remains bullish, suggesting this move is a healthy pullback rather than a trend reversal.

However, if 85K breaks with strong volume, downside liquidity sits around 82K‚Äì80K.

Conclusion:
Hold above 85K = bullish continuation.
Lose 85K = controlled bleed toward 80K, likely a buy-the-dip zone unless market structure fully breaks.

Bitcoin fell by roughly $4,000 after the U.S. market opened, hitting a year-to-date low of $83,900.
Over the past four hours, approximately $540 million in crypto long positions have been liquidated.

With thin liquidity and leveraged positions unwinding simultaneously, market conditions remain highly unstable.

According to Santiment (@santimentfeed), as Bitcoin fell to around $83,200 and altcoins also entered a correction, market participants are divided on whether this move should be seen as a buying opportunity.
While equities, gold, and silver have also seen sharp declines, the sell-off in crypto assets has been particularly severe. In this risk-off environment, price moves in the crypto market are being amplified compared to other asset classes.

At these levels, retail interest in Bitcoin is minimal.
Both trading volume and search trends suggest limited participation, leaving the market in a relatively quiet state.

Whether interest returns‚Äîor the market continues through a phase of time-based consolidation‚Äîremains the key question at this stage.

Gold extends a volatile melt-up as geopolitics and ETF flows drive a new leg higher above $5,000

Gold has just run the full playbook: breakout, pause, vertical spike, and intraday whipsaw. After consolidating near 5,200 dollars, the metal ripped above 5,500, then briefly flushed toward 5,150 before snapping back around 5,300. The message from the tape is clear: trend up, volatility up.

Market trends
‚Ä¢ From 5,200 base to 5,500 spike: between 26‚Äì29 January, gold moved from holding a new range around 5,200 dollars to printing fresh extremes near 5,595 on spot and about 5,626 on futures. The market is trading a new price zone.
‚Ä¢ Geopolitics still in the driver‚Äôs seat: the acceleration came on rising tension in the US‚ÄìIran story, with reports that the Trump administration is weighing a larger strike. The key tell: gold barely reacted to Fed noise, which means the ‚Äúrisk premium‚Äù narrative is dominating rate chatter.
‚Ä¢ Dollar and US politics as a backdrop, not a cap: through midweek, gold held near the highs even as some profit taking showed up. Political uncertainty in the US and renewed debate about future Fed policy, together with a softer dollar at times, kept investors parked in defensive trades.
‚Ä¢ Big money is still buying exposure: iShares Physical Metals issued a large new batch of 1,189,000 iShares Physical Gold ETC units (tranche 2426), on top of multiple smaller issues, including hedged lines. New paper at record prices is a strong signal that institutional demand is strategic.
‚Ä¢ Futures market running hot: CME reported very high daily volumes across the metals complex, with activity in the millions of contracts. That is typical of acceleration phases where both trend followers and short term traders crowd in.

Techs
The last sessions turned the chart into a roller coaster:
Support: 5,150‚Äì5,200 dollars (zone of the sharp dip and prior consolidation)
Resistance: 5,550‚Äì5,600 dollars (recent spike band) and then 5,700 as a stretch target if momentum resumes

The fast drop toward 5,150 and rebound back above 5,300 underline that pullbacks can be violent but have been bought so far.

Equities
Broader equity markets are busy digesting the Fed path and big tech earnings, with US futures edging higher but sentiment still jumpy. Against that backdrop, gold is acting more and more like its own story.
‚Ä¢ Gold as an independent line: the metal pushed higher on geopolitical headlines even when the main talking point of the day was not macro data. That is classic ‚Äúcrisis hedge‚Äù behavior.
‚Ä¢ Mining names echo the move: volatility in producers and royalty names is picking up as investors look for leveraged ways to ride the gold tape. Strong single name moves in companies tied to the gold theme point to capital actively seeking ‚Äúbeta to bullion‚Äù.

Crypto vs Gold
The gap in defensive behavior is widening.
‚Ä¢ In commentary around the move, the angle is simple: when uncertainty steps up, capital is rotating to instruments that look as robust and predictable as possible.
‚Ä¢ Part of the liquidity is leaving crypto. Shrinking stablecoin markets are one sign that risk appetite is being dialed down.
‚Ä¢ Inside crypto, more people are talking about bitcoin as a liquidity and trading tool than as a clean portfolio hedge, while gold is doing the classic ‚Äúgeopolitics up, price up‚Äù pattern almost tick for tick.

What to watch
‚Ä¢ US‚ÄìIran headlines: any confirmation, denial, or escalation around potential US action is likely to move gold more than macro data in the short term.
‚Ä¢ Dollar trend: continued dollar weakness will amplify the move; a sharp dollar rebound could trigger fast but likely temporary dips.
‚Ä¢ ETF and ETC flows: ongoing issuance and inflows into physically backed products remain the cleanest gauge of long term demand.
‚Ä¢ CME volumes and volatility: sustained high turnover supports the current acceleration phase; a drop in volume on new highs would be an early warning of a topping attempt.

Takeaways
‚Ä¢ Gold: the shift from holding 5,200 to spiking above 5,500 shows a market priced on risk premia, not just technical levels. The base case is still a bullish cycle with jagged corrections driven by headlines rather than a smooth grind. Strategy: keep core exposure, and only consider adding on sharp pullbacks if the geopolitical backdrop has not genuinely cooled.
‚Ä¢ Gold linked instruments: continued expansion in physically backed ETC lines confirms institutional sponsorship. This looks less like a one off overshoot and more like the market building a new range above previous all time highs.
‚Ä¢ Crypto: for now, the watchword is patience. Gold is clearly behaving like the primary shock absorber, while crypto remains more sensitive to liquidity swings and sentiment and offers no guaranteed protection in stress phases.

Not financial advice. Always do your own research.

üî• UAE Greenlights Its First USD Stablecoin

While   $BTC grabs attention with price
moves, the UAE just made a structural decision. The country's central bank has approved USDU - its first regulated, dollar-backed stablecoin - directly inside the national payments framework.

This isn't a sandbox experiment. USDU is now regulated under the UAE's Payment Token Services Regulation, placing a USD stablecoin under central bank oversight from day one.

That puts the UAE ahead of most major jurisdictions. Instead of debating stablecoins, it's integrating one into core financial infrastructure a clear signal of long-term intent.

USDU is issued by Universal Digital, regulated by Abu Dhabi Global Market and supervised jointly with the central bank.
That dual oversight means stricter rules on reserves, disclosures, and operations exactly what institutions look for.

The takeaway is simple. This move isn't about hype. It's about stablecoins becoming real financial rails - quietly shaping the next phase of crypto adoption.

While some skeptics still use the tulip bubble comparison, most analysts now consider it a flawed analogy. Unlike the 17th-century tulip mania, which collapsed after only three years and never recovered, Bitcoin has survived for 17 years and rebounded from multiple crashes of 70‚Äì90% to reach new highs.
Key Differences in 2026
 * Institutional Adoption: Bitcoin is now a global asset integrated into financial systems through ETFs and corporate treasuries.
 * Scarcity: Unlike tulips, which can be grown in unlimited quantities, Bitcoin‚Äôs supply is hard-capped at 21 million.
 * Historical Resilience: Bitcoin has weathered "six or seven" major market cycles, whereas the tulip bubble was a one-time local event.
The recent 2026 low below $85,000 is viewed by many as a standard market correction rather than a terminal "burst."
As of today, Thursday, January 29, 2026, Bitcoin is experiencing significant volatility, but the "Tulip Bubble" narrative is once again being challenged by the high level of institutional involvement that simply didn't exist in the 1630s.

Bitcoin‚Äôs hashrate is down ~40% from its all-time high This marks the largest miner capitulation since 2021.  Mining has become unprofitable for a large portion of the network Many miners are shutting down equipment Even falling energy prices are not enough to save margins This is not fear ‚Äî this is economic pressure.  Why this matters? Miners are the backbone of the Bitcoin network. When they are forced to exit: Weak players are flushed out The network resets and becomes healthier Selling pressure from miners eventually dries up Historically, miner capitulation happens near cycle lows, not at the beginning of bear markets.  If we take a look in longer perspective  Some large mining companies will exit crypto entirely Capital and infrastructure will move toward AI, data centers, and energy-related industries Bitcoin mining is becoming a survival game, not an easy business. The Top 7 Leading Crypto Desks for Trading  What Is OTC Trading? $BTC   Over-the-counter OTC trading refers to large digital asset transactions conducted directly between parties, ensuring privacy, fixed pricing, and reduced slippage outside public exchanges. It is tailored for institutions and high-net-worth clients, using private deals or RFQ systems, and serves as essential infrastructure as professional crypto demand expands. Key Features of OTC Platforms - Block trades for large orders - Custom prices from live liquidity - Support from institutional managers - Fiat settlement in USD, EUR, GBP, etc. - Fast, private execution with same-day settlement  Top 7 Crypto OTC Platforms 2026 1. Bitget: Leading OTC desk in 2026 with zero fees, 24/7 trades, deep liquidity, and fiat support in USD, EUR, GBP, TRY, BRL, and ZAR. 2. Coinbase Prime: U.S. OTC desk for institutions, offering block trades, USD settlement, and regulated custody. 3. Binance: Global OTC service using RFQ, supporting wide crypto and fiat pairs with strong liquidity. 4. Kraken: Established OTC desk with manual and automated execution, major fiat support, and direct trader access. 5. Bybit: Crypto-native OTC desk focused on stablecoin and crypto conversions, no fiat support. 6. OKX: Automated OTC venue with 24/7 RFQ, multi-fiat support, and advanced trade strategies. 7. cryptocom: App-based OTC desk with crypto-fiat trades across 20+ currencies, serving high-net-worth and corporate users.  Summary OTC desks are now vital for institutions executing large crypto trades with privacy, speed, and minimal slippage, While Bitget OTC stands out with zero fees, broad asset coverage, multi-currency settlement, and integration with Bitget TradFi, offering unmatched efficiency and flexibility for global professional traders. $CC    SOURCE:-https://www.bitget.com/academy/best-crypto-otc-desks-institutional-trading-platforms-reviewed

$BTC Bitcoin Isn‚Äôt Trading on ‚ÄúNews‚Äù Right Now, It‚Äôs Trading on the Pipes Becoming Unplugged

Everyone is hunting for a macro narrative: the Fed, geopolitical friction, or a value debate. But the tape shows a different reality. Right now, Bitcoin‚Äôs price action is a byproduct of mechanical constraints. This isn't a debate about the future of money; it's an expiry driven liquidity event.

1. The Mechanical Driver: The 30JAN26 Gamma Unpinning
The most important factor right now isn't "bullish" or "bearish" sentiment, it‚Äôs the unwinding of a major share of near dated gamma in the near-dated complex.

The Trap: For much of January, Bitcoin was effectively pinned in the $85k‚Äì$95k range. This was a "hedging-dominated" regime where dealer positioning acted as a shock absorber, dampening volatility in both directions.

The Release: Today, roughly a third of that near-dated gamma rolls off (representing over $8.3B in notional open interest on Deribit alone). This doesn't guarantee a direction, but it removes the guardrails. We are transitioning from a pinned/stable regime to a high-sensitivity regime.

The Vanna Effect: As spot price slid toward $82k, the spike in Implied Volatility (IV) forced dealers to sell spot to stay delta-neutral (Negative Vanna). This is why the drop feels like a "trap door", it‚Äôs a mechanical accelerant, not necessarily a change in fundamental conviction.

2. What the Media is Missing: Selective Liquidity Sourcing
The mainstream story is "Bitcoin is failing while Gold is flying." The first-principles story is about which assets are most "saleable" in a crisis.

Precious Metals Reversal: Gold and silver just printed record nominal highs (Gold recently touched $5,600+ in futures) before snapping back sharply today. Investors are fleeing to safety, but they are also facing a liquidity crunch.

Bitcoin tagged $81K and the realized profit/loss ratio is starting to resemble past transition phases. 

One of the clearest on-chain signals is Glassnode's Realized Profit/Loss Ratio (90-day SMA), a behavioral metric that shows whether $BTC holders are locking in more profits or losses when coins move on-chain. 

By smoothing activity over 90 days, it strips out daily noise and highlights broader market regimes rather than short-term reactions.

Today, this ratio sits in the 1-2 range, meaning that for every $1 of loss being realized, there is still $1-$2 of profit. 

Historically, this exact structure has appeared at key transition points, most notably in April 2018 and February 2022, periods where conviction weakened but full capitulation had not yet arrived.

If this sideways, shallow-bear environment persists, patience could erode further, selling pressure may intensify and the ratio risks slipping below 1, a level that has historically marked late-stage bear markets where losses begin to dominate. 

For a credible shift back toward a bull phase, analysts look for a recovery similar to early 2023, where the ratio stabilized, turned higher and profit realization returned without tipping into euphoria too quickly.

Here's why Fed contender Kevin Warsh is seen as bearish for #Bitcoin    $BTC   fell deeper to nearly $81,000 late Thursday as Warsh's odds surged in betting markets.  On Thursday, President Donald Trump said he will announce his pick for the U.S. Federal Reserve chair to replace incumbent Jerome Powell after the latter's term ends in May.  While nothing is confirmed yet, reports suggest the Trump administration is preparing to nominate Kevin Warsh, who served on the Federal Reserve Board of Governors from 2006 to 2011.    Warsh has occasionally praised cryptocurrencies. Yet bitcoin  BTC plunged late Thursday to near $81,000 lows as his odds spiked on betting sites, with some analysts now pegging him as a bearish force for the asset.  "Markets generally view a resurgence of Warsh's influence as bearish for Bitcoin, as his emphasis on monetary discipline, higher real rates, and reduced liquidity frames crypto not as a hedge against debasement but as a speculative excess that fades when easy money is withdrawn," Markus Thielen, founder of 10x Research, told CoinDesk.  Higher real interest rates mean the actual cost of borrowing money after accounting for inflation is elevated. Think of it as the "true" interest rate that hits your finances harder. When real rates are elevated, businesses and investors typically scale back exposure to risky investments such as bitcoin.  Warsh's track record is adding fuel to the fire. During the global financial crisis (GFC) that lasted from December 2007 to June 2009, Warsh repeatedly cited inflation risks even as the global economy teetered on the brink of a full-blown deflation.  For instance, in September 2008, the month when Lehman Brothers collapsed, Warsh said, "I'm still not ready to relinquish my concerns on the inflation front."

 $BTC saw a very sharp and emotional sell-off recently, breaking several supports and flushing price down into the 81k area. This tells us that the 81k‚Äì81.5k area is a strong demand zone where buyers are willing to defend price.

Crypto Passive Income and Savings

Introduction 
In the modern digital landscape, cryptocurrency has expanded beyond simple buying and selling. More investors are now using crypto as a tool to earn ongoing returns and store value, allowing assets to grow with minimal daily effort. $BTC is often considered a core long-term holding in this space.

How Does Passive Income in Crypto Work?
Passive income in crypto is generated by putting assets to use through options like staking, lending, or contributing to blockchain operations. Instead of frequent trading, users can earn rewards by holding or strategically allocating their digital assets.

Using Crypto for Long-Term Savings

Crypto savings focus on growing digital assets through interest-earning products and reward-based platforms. While these options may offer higher returns compared to traditional savings methods, they also involve exposure to price changes and platform-related risks.
‚úÖÔ∏è Key Risks to Consider
‚úÖÔ∏è Market volatility can impact asset prices
‚úÖÔ∏è Crypto platforms do not provide government-backed protection
‚úÖÔ∏è Higher reward potential often means increased risk
Understanding the product is crucial before committing funds

Conclusion
Crypto passive income and savings offer new ways to build financial growth in the digital age, but they require careful research, risk awareness, and discipline. A balanced strategy combined with a long-term perspective can help users navigate this space responsibly.

Faq
What is crypto passive income?
Earning rewards by holding or allocating crypto, without active trading.
Is active trading required?
No. Returns can be earned through long-term holding strategies.
Are there risks involved?
Yes. Market volatility and platform risks apply.

Which Crypto Exchanges Do Not Report your$BTC  trading  to the IRS?    Decentralized exchanges (DEXs) and certain foreign centralized exchanges (e.g., Bitget) generally do not report user activity to the IRS. Important: All U.S. taxpayers must self-report and pay taxes on worldwide crypto gains and income regardless of forms received. The IRS expands enforcement via blockchain analytics and global cooperation. Non-reporting platforms offer privacy, but no tax exemption. Always track and report; ignorance isn't a defense.  Non-Reporting Exchanges in 2026: Decentralized Exchanges (DEXs), eg. Uniswap, PancakeSwap, 1inch.  Non-U.S.-Based Centralized Exchanges, e.g, Bitget, OSL (Hong Kong). No IRS reporting obligation if they restrict U.S. users. Users must comply with local tax rules. P2P / OTC Platforms Examples: Hodl Hodl, Binance P2P, Pexpay. Direct trades, no custody, typically no IRS forms (some light verification possible). You Still Owe Taxes U.S. residents must report all taxable events (sales, swaps, staking/mining/airdrops rewards) even on non-reporting platforms. Non-compliance risks audits, penalties, or evasion charges. Reporting Exchanges U.S.-based/serving platforms (Coinbase, Kraken, Gemini, Binance.US) issue Form 1099-DA since 2025, reporting gains/sales.Crypto Tax Basics (U.S.) Crypto = property.  Capital gains on disposals (sell/swap/spend).   Ordinary income on earnings (rewards, mining, etc.). Non-taxable: holding, own-wallet transfers, gifts (until sold). Track These for IRS:  Dates acquired/disposed   USD values at those times   Transaction types  Quick FAQ   Risk using non-reporting exchanges? Yes, must self-report.   IRS track DEX trades? Yes, via blockchain.   Forms from DEX/Bitget? No.   Lower taxes this way? No, liability tied to residency/activity.  https://www.bitget.com/academy/which-crypto-exchanges-do-not-report-to-irs

As of this morning, a partial U.S. Government shutdown appears inevitable starting at midnight. While traditional markets and Bitcoin are seeing "risk-off" volatility, the Real-World Asset (RWA) sector is telling a different story of resilience.
1. The Macro Standoff üìâ The Senate remains deadlocked over the Department of Homeland Security funding bill. Unlike previous years, the 2026 market is no longer treating a shutdown as mere political theater. Bitcoin has slipped toward the $84,000 range as institutional investors de-risk from volatile assets in the face of Treasury Department furloughs.

2. The RWA Rotation üîÑ While pure digital assets are seeing outflows, tokenized RWAs (Real-World Assets) are emerging as the preferred safe haven. Why?

For over a decade, US crypto regulation has followed the same loop:

hearings ‚Üí lawsuits ‚Üí market blowups ‚Üí more hearings.

Last week, that loop finally broke.

On Jan 29, 2026, the Senate Agriculture Committee advanced the Digital Commodity Intermediaries Act, the Senate‚Äôs piece of a broader crypto market structure framework. 

It‚Äôs the first time ever such legislation has cleared a Senate committee.
That sentence matters more than it sounds.

Since Bitcoin launched in 2009, zero comprehensive crypto market structure bills had ever made it out of a Senate committee. Not after ICOs. Not after DeFi summer. Not after FTX.

Until now.

This wasn‚Äôt a press release. It was a procedural breakthrough, the kind that decides whether laws ever exist at all.
So what exactly moved?

The bill that passed is the Digital Commodity Intermediaries Act, handled by the Senate Agriculture Committee. It‚Äôs effectively the Senate‚Äôs counterpart to the CLARITY Act, which the House passed in 2025.

Same destination. Different doors.

The Agriculture Committee‚Äôs role is commodities, which tells you immediately where this bill is headed.
At the center of the bill is a long-running question US regulators have avoided answering clearly:

Who actually regulates crypto?

This bill draws a hard line.

Digital commodities - including Bitcoin - fall under the CFTC.

Not just futures. Spot markets too.
That‚Äôs a major shift from regulation-by-enforcement toward regulation-by-design.
The bill also does something Washington has struggled with for years: definitions.

It treats memecoins as digital commodities, not securities.

It explicitly excludes securities and stablecoins, pushing those into a different regulatory lane.

That separation isn‚Äôt accidental. It‚Äôs how lawmakers are trying to untangle years of SEC‚ÄìCFTC turf wars.
But this bill alone doesn‚Äôt become law.

To reach the Senate floor, it must be merged with a separate bill from the Senate Banking Committee, which covers:

‚Ä¢ Security tokens
‚Ä¢ SEC oversight
‚Ä¢ Stablecoin rules

Think of Agriculture and Banking as two halves of the same circuit. Neither works alone
That‚Äôs where the politics get complicated.

The Agriculture bill passed 12‚Äì11 on party lines. Every Republican voted yes. Every Democrat voted no.

Democrats didn‚Äôt object to defining crypto markets ‚Äî they objected to what wasn‚Äôt included.

Specifically: ethics.
During the markup, Democrats pushed amendments to:

‚Ä¢ Prevent public officials from profiting from crypto
‚Ä¢ Add stricter anti-fraud language
‚Ä¢ Block any future crypto bailouts
All of them failed.

Committee leadership argued those issues fall outside Agriculture‚Äôs jurisdiction, meaning they‚Äôre likely to resurface in the Banking Committee instead.
That tension matters because of the math.

To pass the full Senate, this bill needs at least seven Democratic votes. Without bipartisan changes especially around ethics, it doesn‚Äôt move.

Meanwhile, a separate fight has been quietly intensifying: stablecoin yield.

The Senate Banking draft includes Section 404, which would ban crypto platforms from offering yield or interest on stablecoins they custody.

This closes a loophole left open by the GENIUS Act (2025), which regulated stablecoin issuance, but not third-party yields.
That single section has split the industry.

Banks support the ban.
Crypto firms ‚Äî including Coinbase ‚Äî oppose it.

Because yield products sit at the intersection of payments, deposits, and capital markets. Whoever controls that lane controls a lot more than stablecoins.

This is now one of the bill‚Äôs biggest pressure points.
All of this explains why January mattered.

On Jan 26, the White House hosted closed-door meetings with banks, crypto firms, and industry groups to break the stablecoin deadlock.

On Jan 29, regulators relaunched Project Crypto, a joint SEC‚ÄìCFTC initiative focused on:

‚Ä¢ Asset taxonomy
‚Ä¢ Clear jurisdiction
‚Ä¢ Tokenized collateral and market innovation
These weren‚Äôt coincidences. They were coordination.
Zooming out, the pattern is clear.

‚Ä¢ GENIUS Act in 2025 ‚Üí stablecoin foundations
‚Ä¢ CLARITY Act passes the House
‚Ä¢ Senate committees finally move
‚Ä¢ Regulators align publicly

After years of enforcement-first chaos, Washington is building structure slowly, imperfectly, but deliberately.
The most important shift isn‚Äôt who wins SEC vs CFTC.

It‚Äôs that US crypto regulation has moved from:
‚ÄúShould we regulate this?‚Äù
to
‚ÄúHow do we divide responsibility before the next failure?‚Äù

That‚Äôs not hype. That‚Äôs how laws are born.
This bill still has hurdles. It still needs compromise. It still might stall.

But one thing is no longer true:

Crypto market structure in the US is no longer theoretical.

It‚Äôs procedural now.

The "Warsh" Factor: What a New Fed Chair Means for Bitcoin The financial world is on edge today as President Trump prepares to name the next Chair of the Federal Reserve. All signs point to Kevin Warsh, a former Fed Governor with a deep history on Wall Street. For #Bitcoin  holders, thiscould be a major shift in the "rules of the game."  Who is Kevin Warsh? Warsh is often described as a "hawk," which in central bank terms means he prioritizes keeping inflation low and the dollar strong. He‚Äôs known for his "tough love" approach to the economy, often favoring higher interest rates and a smaller Fed balance sheet to prevent the economy from overheating.  The Bitcoin Tug-of-War The reaction in the crypto market has been a mix of caution and curiosity. Here is why his potential appointment is creating a "double-edged sword" for Bitcoin:  The Challenge (Tight Liquidity): Bitcoin usually thrives when #theFed  is "printing money", and interest rates are low. Because Warsh leans toward monetary discipline, some traders fear that a tighter Fed will suck the "easy money" out of the market, putting downward pressure on high-risk assets like $BTC .  The Opportunity (Institutional Respect): Unlike some traditional bankers who dismiss Bitcoin as a "scam," Warsh has recently spoken about it with a level of intellectual respect. He has described Bitcoin as a "significant asset" and even suggested it could act as a "policeman," signaling to the Fed when its own policies are failing.  The Big Picture If Kevin Warsh takes the helm, we may move away from the era of "limitless stimulus." While this might slow down the explosive, "moon-shot" rallies we‚Äôve seen in the past, it could also provide the stability and institutional credibility Bitcoin needs to be taken seriously as a global reserve asset.  The Bottom Line: A Warsh-led Fed might mean a "calmer" Bitcoin, but one that is more deeply integrated into the world's most powerful financial institutions.

US PPI jumped to 3.0% YoY in December 2025, beating expectations and flashing a hotter-than-forecast inflation signal. Core came in at 3.3% (highest since July), with a 0.5% MoM spike in final demand prices doing the damage.

1/ LayerEdge Light Nodes are built for real-world scalability. By keeping computation lightweight, bandwidth usage low, and operations deterministic, the network enables global participation in zk-proof verification using standard consumer hardware. 
2/ Each Light Node verifies only a small randomized subset of proofs, typically 1 to 5 percent of the full batch. Even when batches contain millions of zk-proofs, node workloads stay minimal, allowing efficient operation on laptops, cloud VMs, or edge devices.
3/ To complete verification, nodes download only their assigned proofs and compact Merkle inclusion paths from the data availability layer. This keeps bandwidth low, supports mobile environments, and enables efficient syncing across global networks.
4/ All nodes synchronize using the latest Bitcoin block header as a shared randomness anchor. This prevents manipulation, ensures consistent assignment, and strengthens security while optional checkpointing reduces recomputation for long running batches.

üö® THE #SILVER  MARKET IS SPLIT IN TWO AND THAT IS NOT NORMAL  Silver is currently trading at two very different prices at the same time. On COMEX in the US silver sits near ninety two while in Shanghai physical silver clears close to one hundred thirty. A premium of more than forty percent on the same metal is not inefficiency. It is structural distortion.  The core issue is how silver is priced in different markets. In the US COMEX is dominated by paper contracts. Most volume represents claims not metal. Estimates place the paper to physical ratio around three hundred fifty to one which means hundreds of paper ounces can exist for every real ounce. When large players dump contracts the paper price falls even if no physical silver changes hands. Supply on paper increases instantly while real availability stays tight. $BTC    Shanghai tells a different story. Prices there reflect actual physical transactions where delivery matters. Buyers are not trading leverage. They are sourcing metal. Premiums appear only when supply is constrained and contracts are no longer sufficient. Physical silver holding above one hundred twenty and trading near one hundred thirty shows that demand is immediate and inventory is stressed.  This is why the divergence persists. Where paper dominates prices can be suppressed. Where physical demand dominates prices rise to the level required to clear real supply. COMEX is showing a paper reference. Shanghai is showing the true clearing price.  When a market splits like this it signals that paper pricing no longer represents reality. The gap itself is the evidence. Physical silver is already repricing. The paper market is simply lagging behind. #BTC Price Analysis#  #Macro Insights#
